title: 108_hr5182
content: The Act may be cited as the "Homeland Security Civil Rights and Civil Liberties Protection Act of 2004". The mission of the Department of Homeland Security is outlined in the Act. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to ensure that civil rights and liberties are not diminished in efforts to secure the homeland. Additionally, an Officer for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties is established. Section 705(a) of the Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to address concerns regarding profiling on the basis of race, ethnicity, or religion. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to address concerns about profiling based on race, ethnicity, or religion. The amendment includes provisions to ensure that civil rights and civil liberties are incorporated into Department programs and activities, and to oversee compliance with relevant requirements. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to address concerns about profiling based on race, ethnicity, or religion. Provisions are included to ensure that civil rights and civil liberties are integrated into Department programs and activities, and to oversee compliance with relevant requirements. The Department is required to coordinate with the official appointed under section 222 to address civil rights, civil liberties, and privacy considerations in an integrated manner, and to investigate complaints and information indicating possible abuses of civil rights or civil liberties. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to address concerns about profiling based on race, ethnicity, or religion. Provisions are included to ensure that civil rights and civil liberties are integrated into Department programs and activities, and to oversee compliance with relevant requirements. The Department is required to investigate complaints and information indicating possible abuses of civil rights or civil liberties. SEC. 4. PROTECTION OF CIVIL RIGHTS AND CIVIL LIBERTIES BY OFFICE OF INSPECTOR GENERAL. Designation and Functions of Senior Official. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to ensure civil rights and civil liberties are protected by the Office of Inspector General. Designation of Senior Official within the Office of Inspector General at the Department of Homeland Security to coordinate investigations of abuses of civil rights or civil liberties and review complaints and information. The Office of Inspector General at the Department of Homeland Security is designated to receive and investigate complaints of civil rights abuses by department employees or contractors. Personnel are trained to conduct effective civil rights investigations. The Office of Inspector General at the Department of Homeland Security ensures personnel receive sufficient training for civil rights investigations and consults with the Officer for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties for alleged abuses and policy recommendations. The Office of Inspector General at the Department of Homeland Security ensures proper handling of civil rights investigations, including referring matters not investigated to the Officer for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties. They also ensure public access to information on filing complaints and the status of investigations. The Office of Inspector General at the Department of Homeland Security is responsible for overseeing civil rights investigations and informing the Officer for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties of any issues within the Department related to civil rights or civil liberties. The Office of Inspector General oversees civil rights investigations and informs the Privacy Officer of any related issues within the Department. Section 222 of the Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to include the requirement for coordination with the Officer for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties to ensure programs, policies, and procedures involving civil rights, civil liberties, and privacy. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to include coordination with the Officer for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties to address civil rights, civil liberties, and privacy considerations in an integrated manner. Congress must receive appropriate reports on these programs, policies, and procedures.
